quest_title: The resistance of a wire of uniform diameter '\({d}\)' and length '\({l}\)' is \({R}\). The resistance of another wire of same material but diameter 2\({d}\) and length 2\({l}\) will be
explanation_txt:
\(R^{\prime}=\rho \cfrac{l^{\prime}}{A^{\prime}}\)

\(R^{\prime} \propto \rho \cfrac{l^{\prime}}{\left(d^{\prime}\right)^{2}}\)

\(\Rightarrow \cfrac{R^{\prime}}{R}=\cfrac{l^{\prime}}{\left(d^{\prime}\right)^{2}} \times \cfrac{d^{2}}{l}\)

\(\cfrac{R^{\prime}}{R}=\cfrac{2 l}{(2 d)^{2}} \times \cfrac{d^{2}}{(l)}\)

\(\cfrac{R^{\prime}}{R}=\cfrac{1}{2}\)

\(\therefore \, R^{\prime}=\cfrac{R}{2}\)

quest_title: A tangent galvanometer has a coil with 50 turns and radius equal to 4 cm. A current of 0.1 amp is passing through it. The plane of coil is set parallel to the earth's magnetic meridian. If the value of earth's horizontal component of the magnetic field is 7 \(\times\) 10\({}^{5}\)Tesla and \({\(\mu\)}\)\({}_{0}\) = 4\({\(\pi\)}\)\(\times\) 10\({}^{-7}\) Weber/amp. \(\times\) meter then deflection in the galvanometer needle will be
explanation_txt:
\(I=\cfrac{2 r B}{\mu_{0} n} \tan \theta\)
\( \Rightarrow \tan \theta=\cfrac{I \mu_0 n}{2 r B}=\cfrac{0.1 \times 4 \pi \times 10^{-7} \times 50}{2 \times 0.04 \times 7 \times 10^{-5}} \\ \Rightarrow \tan \theta =1.122 \\ \theta =48.29^{\circ} \)

quest_title: The wavelength of the first line of Lyman series of hydrogen is 1216\(\mathring{A}\). The wavelength of the second line of the same series is
explanation_txt:
For \(1^{\text {st }}\) line
\(\cfrac{1}{\lambda_{\mathrm{L}}}=\mathrm{R}\left[\cfrac{1}{1}-\cfrac{1}{4}\right]\)
\(\therefore \lambda_{\mathrm{L}}=\cfrac{4}{3 \mathrm{R}}\cdots \cdots\) (i)
For \(2^{\text {nd }}\) line
\(\cfrac{1}{\lambda_{\mathrm{L}}^{\prime}}=\mathrm{R}\left[\cfrac{1}{1}-\cfrac{1}{9}\right]\)
\(\therefore \lambda_{\mathrm{L}}^{\prime}=\cfrac{9}{8 \mathrm{R}} \ldots \ldots\) (ii)
Dividing (ii) by (i)
\(\cfrac{\lambda_{\mathrm{L}}^{\prime}}{\lambda_{\mathrm{L}}}=\cfrac{9}{8 \mathrm{R}} \times \cfrac{3 \mathrm{R}}{4}\)
or, \(\lambda_{\mathrm{L}}^{\prime}=\cfrac{27}{32} \times 1216=1026 \mathrm{A}\)

quest_title: There are 60 students in a campus. Each student studies either Science or Arts. The number of science students studying different subjects are 20 in Mathematics, 20 in Physics, 15 in Chemistry, 10 in Mathematics and Physics, 9 in Mathematics and Chemistry, 7 in Physics and Chemistry and 4 in all the three subjects. The number of arts students is:
explanation_txt:
This question is easily solved using venn-diagram. When filling in the numbers, ONLY fill the DISJOINT regions. (Don't fill in for the set of Mathematics students, but fill in for the set of students who study only Mathematics). For the question at hand, start from the students who study all 3 subjects. Then, fill in for the students who study ONLY 2 subjects (by subtracting the intersection of 3 subjects). Laslty, fill in for the students studying ONLY 1 subject. Here is the final result:

This diagram shows the data of Science students. The net total is \(5+7+3+5+6+3+4=33\). Since there are 60 students and each student studies either Science or Arts, the number of students studying arts is \(60-33 = 27\)

quest_title: At what point on the parabola \(y ^ { 2 } = 4 x\), the normal makes equal angles with the co-ordinate axes ?
explanation_txt:
The equation of normal to \(y^2 = 4x \) is \( y = m x - 2 m - m ^ { 3 } \) . For equal angles with coordinate axes, \( m=1 \)

So, equation of normal becomes, \( y = x - 3 \)

The point on parabola is obtained by solving \( y^2 = 4x +12 \Rightarrow y = 6 , -2\)

Hence two points are \( (9,6), (1,-2) \)

But the tangent is perpendicular to the line (hence the line is normal) at only one point. This is to say, slope should be \( -1 \).

Tangent at \( (a,b) \) is \( by = 2 (x‌‌+a) \). So, tangent at \( (9,6) \) is \( 6y = 2x + 18 \) whose slope is \( 1/3 \ne -1 \). Hence the required point is \( (1,-2) \)

quest_title: An element with mass number 27 has 14 neutron in the nucleus of its atom. The element belongs to
explanation_txt:
No of proton = 27 - 14 = 13 = Atomic number

First period = 2 elements

Second period = 8 elements

Third period = 8 elements

So the element belongs to the third group as it's atomic no is greater than 10 and less than 18

So, there exists a phase difference of \(\Delta \phi=\cfrac{\pi }{2} =90{}^\circ \)

quest_title: In how many ways \(n\) books can be arranged in a row so that two specified books are not together?
explanation_txt:
Total number of arrangements of \(n\) books in a row \( = n! \)

Number of arrangements in which two specified books come together \( = 2! \times (n-1)! \)

[Assuming the stack of two books to be 1 and the inter-arrangement of books in the stack is \(2!\) ]

So, required number of ways \( = n! - 2(n-1)! = n(n-1)! - 2(n-1)! = (n-2)(n-1)! \)
question_plain_title: In how many ways books can be arranged in a row so that two specified books are not together?
explanation_plain_text:

Number of arrangements in which two specified books come together

[Assuming the stack of two books to be 1 and the inter-arrangement of books in the stack is ]

So, required number of ways

quest_title: A tank having mirror at bottom is filled with wate upto depth 20cm. An object is hanging at 8cm under the surface of water. The apparent distance if image will be (\(\mu\)\({}_{w}\) = 4/3)
explanation_txt:
\(\quad\)Apparent distance of mirror = \( \cfrac{20}{\mu} \)

\(\quad\)\(\quad\)\(\quad\)\(\quad\) = \( \cfrac{20}{\cfrac{4}{3}} \)= 15cm

\(\quad\)Apparent depth of object = \( \cfrac{8}{\mu} \) = \( \cfrac{8}{4} \times 3 \)= 6cm

\(\quad\)Distance of object from mirror = \(15 - \)6=9cm

\(\quad\)\(\therefore \) Apparent depth of image = 15 + 9 = 24cm
question_plain_title: A tank having mirror at bottom is filled with wate upto depth 20cm. An object is hanging at 8cm under the surface of water. The apparent distance if image will be ( = 4/3)
explanation_plain_text:
Apparent distance of mirror =

= = 15cm

Apparent depth of object = = = 6cm

Distance of object from mirror = 6=9cm

Apparent depth of image = 15 + 9 = 24cm

quest_title: If the ratio of gradients of the lines represented by \(a x ^ { 2 } + 2 h x y + b y ^ { 2 } = 0\) is 1 : 3, then the value of the ratio \(h ^ { 2 } : a b\) is
explanation_txt:
Let \( m_1 = m \) and \(m_2 = 3m \)

Then,

\( m_1 + m_2 = 4m \) and \( m_1m_2 = 3m^2 \)

So, \( -\cfrac{2h}{b} = 4m \) and \(-\cfrac{a}{b} = 3m^2 \)

Squaring the first equation and dividind by second,

\( \cfrac{4h^2}{ab} = \cfrac{16}{3} \)

So, \( \cfrac{h^2}{ab} = \cfrac{4}{3} \)

[ Use, \(4h^2 \lambda = ab (1 + \lambda)^2 \) ]

quest_title: If the numbers \(a,\; b,\; c,\; d,\; e\) form an A.P., then the value of \(a-4b+6c-4d+e\) is
explanation_txt:
Let \(D\) be the common difference of the A.P.

Then, \[ a-4b+6c-4d+e=a-4(a+D)+6(a+2D)-4(a+3D)+(a+4D)=0.\]

[Try putting \(a=1,b=2,c=3,d=4,e=5 \)]

quest_title: A coin placed on a rotating turn table just slips if it is at a distance of 4cm from the centre. If the angular velocity of turn table is doubled it will just slip at a distance of
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{f}}=\mathrm{mr} \omega^{2}=\mu \mathrm{R}\)

Again,

\(\operatorname{mr}^{1}(2 \omega)^{2}=\mu \mathrm{R}\)
or, \(\operatorname{mr}^{1} \times 4 \omega^{2}=\operatorname{mr} \omega^{2}\)
or, \(\mathrm{r}^{\prime}=\mathrm{r} / 4=4 / 4=1 \mathrm{cm}\)

quest_title: The velocity of a body of mass m projected from surface of earth which can reach to a height R/4 from surface of earth is
explanation_txt:
\(\cfrac{1}{2} \mathrm{m} v^{2}-\cfrac{G M m}{R}=\cfrac{G M m}{R+R / 4}\)
or, \(\cfrac{1}{2} \mathrm{m} v^{2}=\cfrac{G M m}{R}-\cfrac{4 G M m}{5 R}=\cfrac{\mathrm{GMm}}{5 \mathrm{R}}=\cfrac{\mathrm{gRm}}{5}\)

\(v=\sqrt{\cfrac{2 \mathrm{gR}}{5}}\)

quest_title: A disc of siren has 80 holes and it is rotated at speed 240 rpm. When a jet of air is blown then a tone is produced. The wavelength of tone in air if speed of sound in air is 320 m/s.
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm{f}=80 \times \cfrac{240}{60}=320 \mathrm{Hz}\)

\(\lambda=\cfrac{v}{\mathrm{f}}=\cfrac{320}{320}=1 \mathrm{m}\)

quest_title: The value of the horizontal component of the earth's magnetic field and angle of dip are \(1.8 \times 10 ^ { - 5 } \text { Weber } / \mathrm { m } ^ { 2 }\) and 30° respectively at some place. The total intensity of earth's magnetic field at that place will be
explanation_txt:
Horizontal component \(B _ { H } = B \cos \phi\)

Total intensity of earth magnetic field \(B = \cfrac { B _ { H } } { \cos \phi }= \cfrac { 1.8 \times 10 ^ { 5 } } { \cos 30 ^ { \circ } } = \cfrac { 1.8 \times 10 ^ { - 5 } } { \sqrt { 3 } / 2 } = 2.08 \times 10 ^ { - 5 } \mathrm { Wb } / \mathrm { m } ^ { 2 }\)
question_plain_title: The value of the horizontal component of the earth's magnetic field and angle of dip are and 30° respectively at some place. The total intensity of earth's magnetic field at that place will be
explanation_plain_text:
Horizontal component

Total intensity of earth magnetic field

quest_title: The following reaction is known to occur in the body \(\text{CO\(_{2}\)}\) + \(\text{H\(_{2}\)O}\)   \(\leftrightharpoons\) \(\text{H\(_{2}\)CO\(_{3}\)}\)   \(\leftrightharpoons\) \(\text{H\(^{+}\)}\)  + \(\text{HCO\(_{3}\)¯.}\) If \(\text{CO\(_{2}\)}\) escapes form the system.
ans4_txt: the forward reaction will be promoted
explanation_txt:
According to Le-Chateliar's principle, the reaction proceeds towards side of decreased concentration.

So, when \(CO_2\) escapes from system, backward reaction is favored. As a result concentration of \(H^+\) drops resulting in drop in pH.
question_plain_title: The following reaction is known to occur in the body + + If escapes form the system.
explanation_plain_text:
According to Le-Chateliar's principle, the reaction proceeds towards side of decreased concentration.

So, when escapes from system, backward reaction is favored. As a result concentration of drops resulting in drop in pH.
ans3_plain_text: concentration will be unaltered
ans4_plain_text: the forward reaction will be promoted

quest_title: The equation of the circle with centre at (1, –2) and passing through the centre of the given circle \(x ^ { 2 } + y ^ { 2 } + 2 y - 3 = 0\) , is
explanation_txt:
According to the question, the required circle passes through (0,–1).

Therefore, the radius is the distance between the points (0, –1) and (1, –2) i.e., \(\sqrt 2\).

Hence the equation is \(( x - 1 ) ^ { 2 } + ( y + 2 ) ^ { 2 } = ( \sqrt { 2 } ) ^ { 2 }\)

\(\Rightarrow x ^ { 2 } + y ^ { 2 } - 2 x + 4 y + 3 = 0\)

[There is only one circle passing through (0,-1) ]

quest_title: The energy of electron in hydrogen atom in its grounds state is --13.6 eV. The energy of the level corresponding to the quantum number equal to 5 is
explanation_txt:
Energy of ground stage \((E_{0} )\) = \(-13.6eV\) and energy level = 5

\[E_{5} =\cfrac{-13.6}{n^{2} } eV=\cfrac{-13.6}{5^{2} } = \cfrac{-13.6}{25} =-0.54eV.\]
question_plain_title: The energy of electron in hydrogen atom in its grounds state is --13.6 eV. The energy of the level corresponding to the quantum number equal to 5 is
explanation_plain_text: Energy of ground stage = and energy level = 5

quest_title: A sample of phosphorus trichloride \((PCl_{3} )\) contains 1.4 moles of the substance. How many atoms are there in the sample
explanation_txt: No. of atoms in one molecule = no. of moles \(\times \, 6.022\times 10^{23} \) \[=1.4\times 6.022\times 10^{23} =8.432\times 10^{23} \]
question_plain_title: A sample of phosphorus trichloride contains 1.4 moles of the substance. How many atoms are there in the sample
explanation_plain_text: No. of atoms in one molecule = no. of moles

quest_title: \(\begin{array} { l } { \text { When } 10 \mathrm { ml } \text { of } 0.1 \mathrm { M } \text { acetic acid } \left( p K _ { a } = 5.0 \right) \text { is titrated } } \\ { \text { against } 10 \mathrm { ml } \text { of } 0.1 \mathrm { M } \text { ammonia solution } \left( p K _ { b } = 5.0 \right) , \text { the } } \\ { \text { equivalence point occurs at } p H } \end{array}\)
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm { p } K _ { a } = - \log K _ { u } , \mathrm { p } K _ { b } = - \log K _ { b }\)

\(\begin{array} { l } { \mathrm { pH } = - \cfrac { 1 } { 2 } \left[ \log K _ { a } + \log K _ { w } - \log K _ { b } \right] } \\ { = - \cfrac { 1 } { 2 } \left[ - 5 + \log \left( 1 \times 10 ^ { - 14 } \right) - ( - 5 ) \right] } \end{array}\)

\(= - \cfrac { 1 } { 2 } [ - 5 - 14 + 5 ] = - \cfrac { 1 } { 2 } ( - 14 ) = 7\)
